doc.previous: In 1944, the University of New Brunswick awarded Innis an honorary degree, as did his alma mater, McMaster University. UniversitÃ© Laval, the University of Manitoba and the University of Glasgow would also confer honorary degrees in 1947â48.[72]
doc.after: In 1945, Innis spent nearly a month in the Soviet Union where he had been invited to attend the 220th anniversary celebrations marking the founding of the country's Academy of Sciences.[73] Later, in his essay, Reflections on Russia, he mused about the differences between the Soviet "producer" economy and the West's "consumer" ethos:
